Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant: Resource Conflicts in a Volatile Borderland

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The researcher, Serkan Yolacan, under the direction of the PI, Ho Enseng of Duke University, will investigate the factors that contribute to the formation and maintenance of transnational networks in a context of resource conflict. The research will take place in Azerbaijan, a state with rich oil reserves off the shores and a region that attracts foreigners of competing agendas and projects. The investigators analyze how external geo-strategic rivalries are driving and becoming entangled with internal rivalries. While some groups within the state ally with the West through oil-driven business networks and military agreements, other more politically and economically marginalized groups have forged regional networks. The increasing visibility of these marginalized groups in the national public space constitutes a challenge to the regime. This project intends to answer how sectarian allegiances with external powers help them build political confidence at home. It aims to explore social networks, historical narratives, and cultural resources that are mobilized vis-à-vis the state elites.

The investigators will undertake a multi-sited ethnographic fieldwork. The research comprises (1) collecting biographical and family histories, (2) following individual itineraries, (3) analyzing textual and oral stories of religious significance as well as actors' own interpretations of these stories. In exploring the mobility, connections, and oral histories, the investigators look to cast new light on the layered landscape of sovereignty in the Middle East and central Eurasia; to have a better insight into the dynamics behind the resilience of regions in a globalized world; and to understand the role of ordinary people in international relations. The research contributes to the education of a graduate student in anthropology. In addition, the research will help us understand an area of the world is strategically important to U.S. national security.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The post-Soviet revival of transnational networks in Azerbaijan is deeply entangled with histories of earlier Azerbaijani mobility across the former domains of the Ottoman, Persian, and Russian empires. Plural in their original make-up, Azerbaijanis occupy a double position in Iranian history. As insiders, they ruled Iran for centuries, beginning with the Safavid dynasty, whose origins lay in Azerbaijan. As outsiders, they opened Iran to the world. Iranian Azerbaijani connections to their kinsmen in the Russian cities of Tbilisi and Baku brought the ideas of constitutionalism from Russia to Iran, and propelled Persia’s constitutional revolution of 1906. Just as they opened Iran to Russia, Azerbaijanis also reconfigured the Ottoman realm, both as Muslim émigrés from Russia and ideologues of pan-Turkism in Istanbul, moving across the Russo-Ottoman frontier.

Azerbaijanis, in other words, thrived as local cosmopolitans connecting the three imperial domains through trade, kinship, and mobility. As locals, they developed deep moral and kinship bonds with peoples in each of these domains, while as cosmopolitans, they maintained links with diasporic Azerbaijanis elsewhere. This study deciphers this Azerbaijani space as a historically interconnected political domain where empires left many cultural strands of their own history and generated what is formulated here as a “cultural surplus” — in other words, diverse vestiges of encounters across and between empires, that cannot be fully captured by any single imperial history. Whereas each empire in time retained only a small subset of the many cultural strands, while leaving out or suppressing others, Azerbaijanis maintained the original cultural surplus, providing both meaning and means for their traveling and dwelling across Ottoman, Persian, and Russian domains.

Azerbaijanis’ local cosmopolitanism, resting on the cultural surplus of three imperial traditions, offers a historically textured understanding of the formation and maintenance of transnational networks that Azerbaijanis navigate in the wider region today. Observers have analyzed the revival of transnational religious, educational, and business networks as political claims by old imperial centers on its peripheries through sectarian idioms. Placing local cosmopolitan Azerbaijanis at the center of Turkish Muslim outreach to former Soviet republics, Iranian Shi’a revivalism in the Middle East, and the reloaded Russian Eurasianism, this project reveals a different view: These new regionalisms, as seen from the perspective of Azerbaijanis, appear to be different but interconnected vectors of a trans-regional cultural space. While the Turkish, Persian, and Russian perspectives on this reemerging space across their political domains are limited by their own national or imperial imaginations, Azerbaijanis possess multiple entryways to each realm thanks to the cultural surplus of three imperial traditions they maintained as local cosmopolitans. Azerbaijanis’ internal empowerment through external connections is thus informed as much by their own diasporic history as by geopolitical rivalry.
